data.title: Lord Rees and Professor Michele Dougherty win Royal Society medals
data.meta_description:
The Royal Astronomical Society congratulates Lord Rees of Ludlow, who has been awarded the Royal Society Copley Medal, and Professor Michele Dougherty of
Imperial Co...
data.text:
The Royal Astronomical Society congratulates Lord Rees of Ludlow, who has been awarded the Royal Society Copley Medal, and Professor Michele Dougherty of Imperial College London, who has won the Bakerian Medal and Lecture.

The Copley Medal was first awarded in 1731 and recognises sustained, outstanding achievements in any field of science. Lord Rees receives the Medal in honour of his conceptual breakthroughs in astrophysics over decades, work with influence far beyond his immediate scientific peers.

Wikipedia / Towards the Light

Professor Dougherty receives her prize in recognition of her scientific leadership on the magnetic field instrument on the Cassini mission to Saturn and its moons, her contribution to the discovery of water on the saturnian moon Enceladus, and her recent leadership of missions set to explore Jupiterâ€™s icy moons.

Professor Mike Edmunds, the President of the Royal Astronomical Society said:
